articles.headline: Unity in the European Market, Except When It Comes to Takeovers
articles.snippet: Mario Monti knows something about blocking deals. While serving as the European Union's antitrust enforcer in 2001, Mr. Monti torpedoed General Electric's takeover of Honeywell -- a brash move that made Brussels a new force in the global markets. ...
articles.abstract: Mario Monti knows something about blocking deals. While serving as the European Union's antitrust enforcer in 2001, Mr. Monti torpedoed General Electric's takeover of Honeywell -- a brash move that made Brussels a new force in the global markets.     Mr. Monti acted in the name of Europe's single market, but the recent rash of blocked deals are different: making it seem as if Europe is splintering into a familiar collection of feuding national interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS, March 13 - Mario Monti knows something about blocking deals. While serving as the European Union's antitrust enforcer in 2001, Mr. Monti torpedoed General Electric's takeover of Honeywell -- a brash move that made Brussels a new force in the global markets.

articles.headline: Deal Takes Capital One to New Turf
articles.snippet: With its $14.6 billion acquisition of the North Fork Bancorporation, Capital One is looking less like a credit card company and more like a traditional bank. But will Wall Street approve?     For years, the success of Capital One, the country's la...
articles.abstract: With its $14.6 billion acquisition of the North Fork Bancorporation, Capital One is looking less like a credit card company and more like a traditional bank. But will Wall Street approve?     For years, the success of Capital One, the country's largest stand-alone credit card issuer, rested on its uncanny ability to innovate, from new products (like zero-interest balance transfers) to new marketing (like a series of clever Viking ads).
articles.lead_paragraph: With its $14.6 billion acquisition of the North Fork Bancorporation, Capital One is looking less like a credit card company and more like a traditional bank. But will Wall Street approve?

articles.headline: About the Tables
articles.snippet: Beginning April 4, The Times will change its daily financial tables, replacing the six existing pages with two pages of analytical tools and summary information on the markets and the economy.     As part of a continuing effort to integrate The Ti...
articles.abstract: Beginning April 4, The Times will change its daily financial tables, replacing the six existing pages with two pages of analytical tools and summary information on the markets and the economy.     As part of a continuing effort to integrate The Times and its Web version, online readers will be able to choose from an array of new functions, including a host of interactive graphics. Readers will also be able to receive closing prices of their stocks and mutual funds by e-mail and will be able to receive midday alerts about sharp price shifts or business news that affects them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beginning April 4, The Times will change its daily financial tables, replacing the six existing pages with two pages of analytical tools and summary information on the markets and the economy.

articles.headline: Expert Suggests Milosevic Died in a Drug Ploy
articles.snippet: A top toxicologist in the Netherlands said Monday that he believed that Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav leader, had been manipulating medication to fake a medical condition, a ploy that contributed to his ill heath and may have played a ro...
articles.abstract: A top toxicologist in the Netherlands said Monday that he believed that Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav leader, had been manipulating medication to fake a medical condition, a ploy that contributed to his ill heath and may have played a role in the heart attack that caused his death.      That theory was advanced by Dr. Donald Uges, professor of clinical and forensic toxicology at the University of Groningen, who suggested that Mr. Milosevic had been seeking to demonstrate that Dutch doctors could not cure him and that he should therefore be allowed to seek treatment, and freedom, in Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE, March 13 - A top toxicologist in the Netherlands said Monday that he believed that Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav leader, had been manipulating medication to fake a medical condition, a ploy that contributed to his ill heath and may have played a role in the heart attack that caused his death.

articles.headline: 2 Asian Automakers Plan Ventures in 2 States Left by U.S. Carmakers
articles.snippet: Two states abandoned by American automobile companies are celebrating new investments by Asian automakers.      Toyota of Japan, the biggest foreign automobile manufacturer in the United States, and Kia from South Korea -- a complete rookie at car...
articles.abstract: Two states abandoned by American automobile companies are celebrating new investments by Asian automakers.      Toyota of Japan, the biggest foreign automobile manufacturer in the United States, and Kia from South Korea -- a complete rookie at car building in America -- both announced new ventures that together would create 3,500 jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAFAYETTE, Ind., March 13 - Two states abandoned by American automobile companies are celebrating new investments by Asian automakers.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Unity in the European Market, Except When It Comes to Takeovers
articles.snippet: Mario Monti knows something about blocking deals. While serving as the European Union's antitrust enforcer in 2001, Mr. Monti torpedoed General Electric's takeover of Honeywell -- a brash move that made Brussels a new force in the global markets. ...
articles.abstract: Mario Monti knows something about blocking deals. While serving as the European Union's antitrust enforcer in 2001, Mr. Monti torpedoed General Electric's takeover of Honeywell -- a brash move that made Brussels a new force in the global markets.     Mr. Monti acted in the name of Europe's single market, but the recent rash of blocked deals are different: making it seem as if Europe is splintering into a familiar collection of feuding national interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS, March 13 - Mario Monti knows something about blocking deals. While serving as the European Union's antitrust enforcer in 2001, Mr. Monti torpedoed General Electric's takeover of Honeywell -- a brash move that made Brussels a new force in the global markets.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Paul Meller

articles.headline: For Bush's Ex-Aide, Quick Fall After Long Climb
articles.snippet: Claude A. Allen often said his religious upbringing took him from a two-room apartment in a poor neighborhood of Washington to a post at the White House.     ''Probably the vast majority of the kids who grew up in our neighborhood were either stru...
articles.abstract: Claude A. Allen often said his religious upbringing took him from a two-room apartment in a poor neighborhood of Washington to a post at the White House.     ''Probably the vast majority of the kids who grew up in our neighborhood were either strung out on drugs or in jail or dead,'' Mr. Allen, one of the nation's most prominent African-American Republicans, said in a televised interview. But Mr. Allen said his salvation was the Roman Catholic education ''that taught me discipline, taught me hard work, that taught me values that were carried throughout life.''
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 13 - Claude A. Allen often said his religious upbringing took him from a two-room apartment in a poor neighborhood of Washington to a post at the White House.
articles.byline: By Ian Urbina and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Judge Calls Halt to Penalty Phase of Terror Trial
articles.snippet: An angry federal judge delayed the sentencing trial of Zacarias Moussaoui on Monday and said she was considering ending the prosecution's bid to have him executed after the disclosure that a government lawyer had improperly coached some witnesses....
articles.abstract: An angry federal judge delayed the sentencing trial of Zacarias Moussaoui on Monday and said she was considering ending the prosecution's bid to have him executed after the disclosure that a government lawyer had improperly coached some witnesses.     Judge Leonie M. Brinkema said she had just learned from prosecutors that a lawyer for the Transportation Security Administration gave portions of last week's trial proceedings to seven witnesses who have yet to testify. In e-mail messages, the lawyer also seemed to tell some of the witnesses how they should testify to bolster the prosecution's argument that Mr. Moussaoui bore some responsibility for the deaths caused by the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 13 - An angry federal judge delayed the sentencing trial of Zacarias Moussaoui on Monday and said she was considering ending the prosecution's bid to have him executed after the disclosure that a government lawyer had improperly coached some witnesses.

articles.headline: Study Links Ambien Use to Unconscious Food Forays
articles.snippet: The sleeping pill Ambien seems to unlock a primitive desire to eat in some patients, according to studies.
articles.abstract: The sleeping pill Ambien seems to unlock a primitive desire to eat in some patients, according to studies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sleeping pill Ambien seems to unlock a primitive desire to eat in some patients, according to emerging medical case studies that describe how the drug's users sometimes sleepwalk into their kitchens, claw through their refrigerators like animals and consume calories ranging into the thousands.

articles.headline: Road to Rebirth Diverges on a Mississippi Bridge
articles.snippet: At the eastern tip of this city there was once a bridge. Like much of the Mississippi Gulf Coast, it was reduced by Hurricane Katrina to a muddle of concrete and pilings, tumbled over like a giant line of dominos.      Everyone wants it rebuilt as...
articles.abstract: At the eastern tip of this city there was once a bridge. Like much of the Mississippi Gulf Coast, it was reduced by Hurricane Katrina to a muddle of concrete and pilings, tumbled over like a giant line of dominos.      Everyone wants it rebuilt as soon as possible. But officials on one side of the bridge -- those in Biloxi -- favor a large, multilane structure that can accommodate casino workers and the new horde of gamblers. On the other side, in Ocean Springs, officials want to restore the four-lane drawbridge that once spanned the bay, hoping to keep their French-colonized, tree-lined town the definition of quaint.
articles.lead_paragraph: BILOXI, Miss. - At the eastern tip of this city there was once a bridge. Like much of the Mississippi Gulf Coast, it was reduced by Hurricane Katrina to a muddle of concrete and pilings, tumbled over like a giant line of dominos.

articles.headline: Colleges Open Minority Aid to All Comers
articles.snippet: Facing threats of litigation and pressure from Washington, colleges and universities nationwide are opening to white students hundreds of thousands of dollars in fellowships, scholarships and other programs previously created for minorities.     S...
articles.abstract: Facing threats of litigation and pressure from Washington, colleges and universities nationwide are opening to white students hundreds of thousands of dollars in fellowships, scholarships and other programs previously created for minorities.     Southern Illinois University reached a consent decree last month with the Justice Department to allow nonminorities and men access to graduate fellowships originally created for minorities and women.

articles.headline: Study Links Ambien Use to Unconscious Food Forays
articles.snippet: The sleeping pill Ambien seems to unlock a primitive desire to eat in some patients, according to emerging medical case studies that describe how the drug's users sometimes sleepwalk into their kitchens, claw through their refrigerators like anima...
articles.abstract: The sleeping pill Ambien seems to unlock a primitive desire to eat in some patients, according to emerging medical case studies that describe how the drug's users sometimes sleepwalk into their kitchens, claw through their refrigerators like animals and consume calories ranging into the thousands.     The next morning, the night eaters remember nothing about their foraging. But they wake up to find telltale clues: mouthfuls of peanut butter, Tostitos in their beds, kitchen counters overflowing with flour, missing food, and even lighted ovens and stoves. Some are so embarrassed, they delay telling anyone, even as they gain weight.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sleeping pill Ambien seems to unlock a primitive desire to eat in some patients, according to emerging medical case studies that describe how the drug's users sometimes sleepwalk into their kitchens, claw through their refrigerators like animals and consume calories ranging into the thousands.

articles.headline: McClatchy to Resell 12 Papers It's Buying
articles.snippet: There was both joy and despair across the Knight Ridder newspaper chain as employees learned that the McClatchy Company, which announced plans yesterday to acquire the company's 32 papers, would promptly sell 12 of them.     Those at the Knight Ri...
articles.abstract: There was both joy and despair across the Knight Ridder newspaper chain as employees learned that the McClatchy Company, which announced plans yesterday to acquire the company's 32 papers, would promptly sell 12 of them.     Those at the Knight Ridder papers being kept by McClatchy -- including The Miami Herald and The Charlotte Observer -- will be working for a family-controlled business known for disciplined management and solid journalistic standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was both joy and despair across the Knight Ridder newspaper chain as employees learned that the McClatchy Company, which announced plans yesterday to acquire the company's 32 papers, would promptly sell 12 of them.
